Patient Visit Notes
Date: October 15, 2023
Dr. Sarah Chen
Patient presents with complaints of headache and fatigue. The headache has been occurring intermittently for the past 3 days, with patient rating pain at 6/10. Patient describes the headache as primarily affecting the frontal region, with no accompanying visual disturbances. The fatigue has been constant for approximately one week, rated at 4/10 severity, and is most noticeable in the afternoons.
Patient has been self-managing symptoms with over-the-counter ibuprofen 200mg as needed, reporting moderate relief when taken.
Review of allergies confirms known sensitivities to pollen and dust mites. Patient uses air purifiers at home to help manage environmental allergies.
Patient maintains good sleep hygiene with regular 7-hour sleep schedule and stays well-hydrated. Regular exercise routine includes 30-minute walks three times per week.
Plan:

Continue current ibuprofen regimen as needed
Recommended keeping a symptom diary to track headache triggers
Follow-up in two weeks if symptoms persist
Encouraged to maintain current exercise routine

Next appointment scheduled for October 29th at 2:30 PM.

PATIENT VISIT NOTES
Date: October 15, 2023
Provider: Dr. Sarah Chen
CHIEF COMPLAINT:
Patient presents with persistent cough and breathing difficulties.
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
Patient reports a cough that started 14 days ago, describing it as occasionally occurring with moderate to severe intensity (7/10). Over the past 5 days, patient has also been experiencing intermittent shortness of breath (8/10 severity). Today, patient reported new onset chest pain (5/10 severity). Patient works as a school teacher and notes symptoms are particularly bothersome while speaking to students.
CURRENT MEDICATIONS:

Albuterol inhaler: 2 puffs every 4-6 hours as needed for breathing difficulties
Prednisone: 20mg once daily

FAMILY HISTORY:
Significant for asthma (maternal side) and hypertension (both parents).
REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:
Temperature 98.6°F, BP 122/78, pulse 82, respiratory rate 18. Patient is alert and oriented, speaking in complete sentences though occasionally interrupted by cough. Lungs demonstrate mild wheezing in upper fields. Heart sounds regular with no murmurs. Remainder of physical exam unremarkable.
ASSESSMENT:
Presenting symptoms consistent with acute bronchial exacerbation. Patient maintains good oxygen saturation despite symptoms.
PLAN:

Continue current medication regimen
Follow up in one week or sooner if symptoms worsen
Advised to use humidifier at night
Recommended to avoid known respiratory irritants

Patient verbalizes understanding of treatment plan and follow-up instructions

PATIENT VISIT NOTES
Date: October 12, 2023
Provider: Dr. Sarah Chen
SUBJECTIVE:
Patient presents with complaints of nausea for the past 2 days. Describes the nausea as moderate (6/10 severity), occurring occasionally throughout the day. Patient notes that symptoms tend to be worse in the morning. Patient has been able to maintain hydration but reports decreased appetite.
ALLERGIES:
Known allergy to penicillin.
CURRENT MEDICATIONS:
Taking ondansetron 4mg every 8 hours as needed for nausea.
REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:
Vital signs stable. Patient is alert and oriented. Skin warm and dry. No signs of dehydration. Abdomen soft and non-tender on examination.
ASSESSMENT & PLAN:

Nausea - likely viral gastritis. Current medication regimen with ondansetron appears appropriate.
Patient counseled on maintaining fluid intake and following BRAT diet.
Return to clinic if symptoms worsen or persist beyond 5 days.
Follow-up appointment scheduled for next week if needed.

Patient expressed understanding of treatment plan and recommendations.
Time spent with patient: 15 minutes

Patient Visit Notes
Date: October 15, 2023
Provider: Dr. Sarah Chen
Chief Complaint:
Patient presents with ongoing joint pain and stiffness.
History of Present Illness:
Patient reports experiencing constant joint pain and stiffness for the past 30 days. The joint pain is rated as 7/10 in severity, while the stiffness is rated as 6/10. Pain is particularly noticeable in the morning and affects multiple joints, including knees and wrists. Patient maintains an active lifestyle but has had to reduce participation in regular swimming activities due to symptoms.
Current Medications:

Methotrexate 10mg once weekly
Folic acid 1mg once daily

Family History:
Significant for diabetes, heart disease, and cancer. Father diagnosed with type 2 diabetes at age 55, maternal grandmother had breast cancer, and paternal grandfather had coronary artery disease.
Review of Systems:
Musculoskeletal: As noted in HPI
Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no chest pain
Respiratory: No shortness of breath
Constitutional: No fever, maintaining normal appetite and weight
Physical Examination:
Vital signs stable. Patient appears well-groomed and in mild discomfort. Joints show mild swelling but no erythema. Range of motion slightly limited in affected joints. Grip strength slightly diminished bilaterally.
Assessment & Plan:

Will continue current medication regimen
Recommended gentle stretching exercises
Follow-up appointment in 4 weeks
CBC and CMP to be done prior to next visit

Patient verbalized understanding of treatment plan and will call if symptoms worsen.

Patient Visit Notes - 09/15/2023
Dr. Sarah Chen
Patient presents with a persistent rash that has been present for 5 days. The rash appears continuous throughout the day (constant), and patient rates discomfort level at 4/10. Rash is primarily located on inner forearms and shows no signs of infection.
Patient reports feeling otherwise healthy and maintains regular exercise routine of swimming 3x weekly. Vital signs normal, with BP 118/76, pulse 72, temperature 98.6°F.
Allergies documented:

Latex
Shellfish
Peanuts

Family history notable for maternal grandmother's lupus (other). No family history of diabetes, heart disease, cancer, asthma, or hypertension.
Patient continues to work full-time as a high school teacher and reports good stress management through regular meditation practice.
Plan:

Prescribed topical hydrocortisone cream
Advised to monitor rash and return if symptoms worsen
Recommended keeping detailed diary of potential environmental triggers
Follow-up in 2 weeks if no improvement

Next scheduled routine physical: March 2024
